awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Developing a Unified Framework for the Dynamics and Structure of Organisms, Cities and Companies
awd_abstract_narration:
The major thrust of this project is to develop a quantitative and predictive unified framework for understanding the coarse-grained structure and dynamics of biological and social systems across all scales from cells and multicellular organisms to ecosystems, cities and companies. Techniques from mathematics and physics such as network theory, field theory and non-linear dynamics, scaling and the renormalization group, as well as numerical simulations, will be used where appropriate but crucially and necessarily in convergent collaboration with theorists, experimentalists, and practitioners in the multiple fields with which the work overlaps. Developing a science of cities to complement traditional, more qualitative approaches is urgently required to address global sustainability. Can we maintain a vibrant, innovative society driven by ideas and wealth creation or are we destined to a planet of slums, conflict and devastation? The ever-increasing pace of life and increasingly rapid rate of change driven by positive feedback mechanisms in social networks induces serious stress across all aspects of life. Is this sustainable or are we headed for major disruptions to the socio-economic fabric? To address these issues a new conceptual framework is needed, encompassing a quantitative theory of cities, a Grand Unified Theory of Sustainability that integrates across the multiplicity of challenges we face.

This is an ambitious program that transcends conventional disciplinary boundaries, ranging across the mathematical, physical, biological and social sciences, with potentially important implications for addressing societal issues such as aging, cancer, urbanization and global sustainability. The two main categories to be explored are i) a generic theory of aging, damage, sleep and repair; and (ii) developing a science of cities, urbanisation and global sustainability. Although the overall goal will be to explore the development of a potential unified framework for quantitative understanding of how these diverse, highly complex evolving systems can be understood from a parsimonious mathematically quantifiable set of underlying principles and concepts, this will be carried out in the context of focusing on several specific problems such as: how are lifetimes whose scale is years generated from microscopic molecular time scales associated with genes and respiratory enzymes? Why is the half-life of US publicly-traded companies about 10 years? Why, on average, do all companies and organisms stop growing and die but almost all cities keep growing and remain viable? Does the scaling of sleep times from babies to adults recapitulate how it scales from mice to elephants? Is there a maximum or optimum size of cities?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report: A Unifying Framework for the Dynamics and Structure of Organisms, Ecosystems, Cities and Companies

 

Geoffrey B. West

Santa Fe Institute

 

The major goal of this research was to explore the possibility of developing a quantitative, predictive unifying framework for understanding the generic structure and dynamics of biological and social systems across multiple scales ranging from the microscopic to the macroscopic: from cells and multicellular organisms to ecosystems, cities and companies. This is an ambitious program that transcends conventional disciplinary boundaries, ranging across the mathematical, physical, biological and social sciences, with potentially important implications for addressing major societal issues such as aging, cancer, urbanization and global sustainability.

The program was inspired by the observation that despite their extraordinary complexity and diversity, many of life's most fundamental and complex phenomena scale in a very simple way with size, manifesting universal properties that transcend their structure and history. In biology, these include metabolic rates, lifespans, genome lengths, RNA densities, and cerebral white and gray matter; in cities and companies they include wages, assets, profits, crime, patents, disease, pollution, and transport. Such systematic behavior across all scales in systems with vastly different evolved designs and functions strongly suggests that there are underlying hidden emergent dynamics, principles and laws that have operated on and constrained all evolutionary processes. These originate in the dynamical and mathematical properties of optimized, fractal-like, branching networks that sustain life at all scales, such as vascular networks in biology and social and transportation networks in socio-economic systems.

This framework was used to address a series of major questions. These included a theory of sleep and neural development during early growth (ontogeny); the organizational structure and dynamics of universities; the nature of the Anthropocene; inequality in cities; the scaling and growth of companies; a general law of urban mobility; resolving the paradox of how cancer risk scales across species; growth, death, and resource competition in sessile organisms; the temperature dependence of living processes; and the physical constraints on evolution.

i) A mechanistic theory for understanding sleep was used to quantitatively explain why sleep times systematically change both across species (why mice sleep twice as long as humans and four times that of whales) and during development (why babies sleep twice as long as adults). Among our major findings we discovered a dramatically abrupt transition in the function of sleep at approximately 2.4 years old. Before this, sleep functions primarily for neural reorganization and learning, and occurs primarily during REM sleep, whereas after it and into late ontogeny and maturity, sleep functions predominantly for brain repair.

ii) We investigated the scalability, efficiency and complexity of Universities and Colleges and showed that they too scale in a similar systematic fashion. Metrics included expenditures, revenues, graduation rates and estimated economic added value, as functions of total enrollment. We highlighted the strong complementarity between public and private research universities, and community and state colleges. This analysis provides a fundamentally new framework for informing policymakers and administrators with a powerful tool for understanding the roles of their institution and for assessing, in a scientific framework, their performance relative to other institutions.

iii) The Great Acceleration, the dramatic post-1950 change in earth and human systems indicators, is the signature pattern of the Anthropocene and is potentially moving humanity past planetary boundaries. It is driven by the increase in global population, attributed to some of the metrics defining the Great Acceleration in a positive feedback loop. In order to reveal underlying dynamics, we applied a scaling analysis to uncover fine-grained patterns within each decade that revealed the taxonomy of these feedback loops and driving mechanisms. We showed that socioeconomic, technological, information, biological and earth systems, when scaled to population size, sort into four distinct growth regimes, suggesting fundamental differences in the underlying network of interactions causing the observed patterns of change that have major consequences for designing possible interventions.

iv) We proposed the urban scaling framework as a new method for studying income inequality in cities: how does it change with city size and are poor people in a larger city better off than poor people in a small city? We showed that income in the least wealthy decile (bottom 10%) scales close to linearly with city population, while income in the most wealthy decile (top 90%) scales significantly faster (i.e., systematically more per capita the bigger the city). Consequently, for the poorest income deciles, cities have little or no positive benefits, whereas the richest deciles reap the major benefits larger cities offer, such as greater GDP, higher wages, and more patents per capita, even after adjusting for cost of living such as housing costs. Our work suggests that cities with high levels of economic segregation inhibit mixing between diverse populations, and consequently underperform with respect to income scaling.
